turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Bartitsu.
turn.1: What was the training like in Bartitsu?
turn.2: It is evident that Bartitsu classes included pre-arranged exercises, especially for use in rehearsing those techniques that were too dangerous to be performed at full speed or contact, as well as free-sparring and fencing bouts.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: According to an anonymous article published in "The Sketch" of April 10, 1901, these sessions may have involved a type of circuit training in which students would rotate between small group classes taught by each of the specialist instructors.
turn.5: What types of techniques were used?
turn.6: Many Bartitsu self-defence techniques and training sequences were recorded by Barton-Wright himself in his series of articles for "Pearson's Magazine.
turn.7: What did the training lead to?
turn.8: " The specific details of other Bartitsu stick fighting training drills were recorded in Captain Laing's article.
turn.9: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.10: By mid-1902, the Bartitsu Club was no longer active as a martial arts school.
turn.11: Why did the school close down?
turn.12: The precise reasons for the Club's closure are unknown, but jiujitsu instructor William Garrud subsequently suggested that both the enrollment fees and tuition fees had been too high.
